Through participation and leadership, members of civil society are habituated in observing their shared values, cooperating with their fellow men, and ultimately in practicing self-government.

The mediating institutions “mediate” by securing for the individual a space for participation, membership, & belonging within the broader society. In this way, civil society is thought to prevent individuals’ estrangement and alienation from mass society.  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis/?id=78A35E07-4C86-44A2-8480-BE0DB8CB104E …

Structural independence enables civil society to serve a functional role as a set of “mediating institutions.” Institutions—the durable social arrangements we create together to achieve common goals in the course of interacting with one another—are instituted for many reasons.

Civil society constitutes a kind of “third sector” within society. It exists independently of both government, or the “public sector,” and the market, or “private sector.” Learn more about the importance of civil society in America ↓

The Social Capital Project envisions 5 mediating institutions that can be renewed to address declining civil society: 
🏘 Neighborhoods
⛪️ Churches
🏫 Schools
🏇🏽 Voluntary associations
💰 Philanthropy

✨The Future of Education✨
The next generation of education reform should focus on enlivening the role of authentic communities in schools, both to expand opportunity to low-income students and to invigorate the role of civil society in creating norms and a sense of belonging.

American civil society has evolved over the last two centuries. 
Find out how in our latest report👉🏼 https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=78A35E07-4C86-44A2-8480-BE0DB8CB104E … https://twitter.com/DKThomp/status/1207349303276179456 …

American civil society has been hollowed out. The task of concerned policymakers and citizens alike must now be to discern what can be done to renew these institutions that were once so central to American life—and that could be again. Learn more ↓

The latest paper from The Social Capital Project focuses on rebuilding civil society. It lays out the nature of our diminished civil society, documents trends in its decline, and charts a path to its renewal. Read the report below ↓
NEW: Our latest report, "The Space Between: Renewing the American Tradition of Civil Society," is live on our website ⬇️

Education came to be re-conceptualized as a method of training productive workers, building human capital, and encouraging industriousness. Read more:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=BFFED882-7A9E-4462-AC0B-69ED4E67D663 … pic.twitter.com/k84bav0LAB

Public education became more centralized and more professionalized — the number of school districts fell from over 100,000 in 1940 to fewer than 14,000 today.  It also ceded its aspirations towards moral formation.

Over the past century and a half, delivery of educational services has been predominately state-funded and state-operated. State provision of education has proved remarkably stable. pic.twitter.com/g9SSQoX83R

A focus on choice dominated the education policy landscape for most of the 1990s and early 2000s, with an equilibrium that favored limited choice within the public school system, through open enrollment and charter schools. pic.twitter.com/AcdHw2ATsd

ICYMI: Our latest paper, "Multiple Choice: Increasing Pluralism in the American Education System" is available on our website. Learn about the history of education in America, the benefits of education pluralism, and more ⬇️

To many Americans, private education is a deviation from the status quo. But compared to other industrialized nations, the American system of state-provided education is an outlier.
Learn more about the education systems of: 
#Sweden
#Denmark
#UK
#Australia
#France 
& more👇🏼
Find out how education pluralism can increase confidence in the American education system:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=BFFED882-7A9E-4462-AC0B-69ED4E67D663 …

In a recent survey, a majority of all household income groups, and nearly all racial groups, said that they would prefer to send their child to private, rather than public, school, if costs were the same.

Confidence in public education has been declining. In 1975, 62% of parents expressed having confidence in the public schools. By 2019, the fraction expressing confidence, 29% of respondents, was exactly equal to those with little or none.

The adoption of magnet schools, gifted programs, English as a Second Language classes, and other tailored approaches reflect a recognition that students are better served by an individualized approach, surrounded by peers with similar goals and challenges:  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=BFFED882-7A9E-4462-AC0B-69ED4E67D663 … pic.twitter.com/36R9rU7IyZ
Even within the American public education system, some policymakers have recognized the limits of a one-size-fits-all approach 👇🏼 pic.twitter.com/WAswArzG9g

A pluralist approach to education recognizes the importance of social capital, appreciates the value of authentic diversity, acknowledges the importance of meaningful civic engagement, and encourages excellence across school types and sectors.

Fully 5.5 million students attend private school, three million attend public charter schools, and just under two million are homeschooled. Half a million students now participate in a private school choice program. 👉🏼 https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis/?id=BFFED882-7A9E-4462-AC0B-69ED4E67D663 …
Today, 56.5 million students attend a public or private elementary or secondary school in the United States, 89% of whom attend an assigned or chosen public school. pic.twitter.com/GHdjVECWCW

THREAD: From 2000 to 2018, the number of students participating in a private school choice program increased 16 times over, while participation in public charter programs increased nearly seven-fold. pic.twitter.com/nWrloFHR1a

Our latest paper by @PTBwrites explores the case for an explicitly pluralistic conception of education and highlights policy options that could increase the degree of pluralism within our educational system. Read more ⬇️  https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis/?id=BFFED882-7A9E-4462-AC0B-69ED4E67D663 …

The American education system makes it difficult for parents to tailor their children’s educational experience. We must increase the role of civil society in education, ensure a diversity of educational paths, providers, and philosophies, & hold providers to clear standards.

Investing in children relies on social capital — the value embedded in relationships, interpersonal networks, and connection to institutions. Ideally, schools formalize community relationships and embody the values and traditions of the community.

The JEC’s #SocialCapitalProject has adopted improving the effectiveness of youth investment, and particularly strengthening parents’ ability to invest in children, as one of its core goals. Learn how increasing pluralism in the American education system can help in this effort:
